title: Jeremiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 38 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 38.

questions.question: Who heard the words that Jeremiah had spoken unto all the people according to Jeremiah 38:1?
options: Shephatiah, Gedaliah, Jucal, and Pashur
Ebedmelech, Zedekiah, and Jeremiah
The king of Babylon and his army
The priests and Levites
questions.correctAnswer: Shephatiah, Gedaliah, Jucal, and Pashur
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:1 states that Shephatiah the son of Mattan, Gedaliah the son of Pashur, Jucal the son of Shelemiah, and Pashur the son of Malchiah heard Jeremiah's words.

questions.question: What did the LORD say would happen to those who remain in the city according to Jeremiah 38:2?
options: They shall die by the sword, famine, and pestilence
They shall prosper and be safe
They shall be taken captive but live
They shall be given riches and peace
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die by the sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:2 says those remaining in the city will die by the sword, famine, and pestilence, but those who go to the Chaldeans shall live.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 38:3, who will take the city?
options: The king of Babylon's army
The Egyptians
The Ammonites
The Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Babylon's army
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:3 states that the city will be given into the hand of the king of Babylon's army, which shall take it.

questions.question: What did the princes ask the king to do to Jeremiah according to Jeremiah 38:4?
options: Put him to death
Send him to Babylon
Make him a priest
Give him a reward
questions.correctAnswer: Put him to death
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:4 shows the princes asking the king to put Jeremiah to death because they believed his words weakened the morale of the people.

questions.question: Where was Jeremiah cast into according to Jeremiah 38:6?
options: The dungeon of Malchiah
The king's palace
The house of the LORD
The city gate
questions.correctAnswer: The dungeon of Malchiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:6 states that Jeremiah was taken and cast into the dungeon of Malchiah, which was in the court of the prison.

questions.question: Who intervened to save Jeremiah from the dungeon according to Jeremiah 38:7-10?
options: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian
Gedaliah the son of Pashur
Zedekiah the king himself
Jucal the son of Shelemiah
questions.correctAnswer: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:7-10 describes how Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, a eunuch in the king's house, heard of Jeremiah's plight and spoke to the king to save him.

questions.question: What did Ebedmelech use to help lift Jeremiah out of the dungeon according to Jeremiah 38:11-13?
options: Old cast clouts and rotten rags
Ropes made of silk
A ladder from the king's house
A basket and pulley
questions.correctAnswer: Old cast clouts and rotten rags
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:11-13 explains that Ebedmelech took old cast clouts and rotten rags, put them under Jeremiah's arms under the cords, and then drew him up.

questions.question: Where did Jeremiah remain after being lifted from the dungeon according to Jeremiah 38:13?
options: In the court of the prison
In the king's house
In the temple
In the city gate
questions.correctAnswer: In the court of the prison
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:13 states that after being drawn up, Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison.

questions.question: What did King Zedekiah promise Jeremiah according to Jeremiah 38:16?
options: He would not put him to death nor give him into his enemies' hands
He would exile him to Babylon
He would crown him as a prophet
He would imprison him for life
questions.correctAnswer: He would not put him to death nor give him into his enemies' hands
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:16 records Zedekiah swearing secretly that he would neither put Jeremiah to death nor hand him over to those seeking his life.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 38:17, what will happen if Zedekiah goes forth to the king of Babylon's princes?
options: His soul shall live, the city shall not be burned, and his house will live
The city will be destroyed and he will be captured
He will be mocked and rejected
He will lose his kingdom but save his family
questions.correctAnswer: His soul shall live, the city shall not be burned, and his house will live
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:17 states that if Zedekiah goes to the king of Babylon's princes, his soul will live, the city will not be burned, and his house will survive.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah was afraid to speak the words of the LORD to King Zedekiah because he feared the king would kill him. (Jeremiah 38:15)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:15 shows Jeremiah asking Zedekiah if he will kill him if he declares the word of the LORD, indicating his fear.

questions.question: True or False: Zedekiah was afraid of the Jews who had fallen to the Chaldeans because he feared they would mock him. (Jeremiah 38:19)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:19 records Zedekiah expressing fear that the Jews who fell to the Chaldeans would deliver him and mock him.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah was immediately put to death after the princes questioned him about his words. (Jeremiah 38:27)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:27 states the princes questioned Jeremiah, but no harm came to him, and he remained in the prison court.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 38:6: 'And in the dungeon there was no water, but ______: so Jeremiah sunk in the mire.'
options: mire
fire
darkness
sand
questions.correctAnswer: mire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:6 says there was no water in the dungeon but mire, causing Jeremiah to sink in it.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 38:24: 'Then said Zedekiah unto Jeremiah, Let no man ______ of these words, and thou shalt not die.'
options: know
hear
judge
speak
questions.correctAnswer: know
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:24 records Zedekiah telling Jeremiah to let no man know of these words so he would not die.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 38 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged because speaking God's truth causes opposition, as happened to Jeremiah. Based on Jeremiah 38, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God when facing trials?
options: Obedience to God's word may bring hardship, but God preserves and vindicates His servants.
Avoid speaking God's word if it causes trouble among people.
Seek to please people rather than God to avoid persecution.
Disregard God's warnings to maintain peace with others.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's word may bring hardship, but God preserves and vindicates His servants.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was cast into a dungeon for speaking God's warning (Jeremiah 38:4-6), yet God used Ebedmelech to rescue him (38:7-13) and preserved his life. This teaches that faithfulness to God despite opposition leads to His protection and vindication (38:16-17, 38:28).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 38 illustrate the importance of interceding and serving others in the church community?
options: Ebedmelech's intervention to save Jeremiah demonstrates courage and faithfulness in serving others in need.
One should ignore the suffering of others to avoid trouble.
Only kings and leaders can help, not servants.
Serving others is unnecessary if they are unpopular.
questions.correctAnswer: Ebedmelech's intervention to save Jeremiah demonstrates courage and faithfulness in serving others in need.
questions.explanation: Ebedmelech, a eunuch in the king's house, heard Jeremiah's plight and boldly asked the king to rescue him (38:7-10). He then personally helped by lowering rags to protect Jeremiah as he was lifted out (38:11-13). This shows practical love and service within the community (38:7-13).

questions.question: Jeremiah 38 warns about consequences of disobedience and fear. How does this chapter teach us about the importance of obedience and courage in leadership?
options: Leaders must obey God's commands even when fearful, as Zedekiah was urged to do.
Leaders should prioritize their safety by avoiding difficult decisions.
Fear justifies ignoring God's warnings for peace.
Leaders should rely only on their own wisdom without seeking God's guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must obey God's commands even when fearful, as Zedekiah was urged to do.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah counseled King Zedekiah to surrender to Babylon for life and preservation (38:17-18). Although Zedekiah feared the Jews (38:19), Jeremiah urged obedience to God's voice for his safety (38:20). This emphasizes courage and obedience in leadership (38:14-20).

questions.question: In the face of rejection and suffering, what biblical virtue does Jeremiah's experience in the dungeon teach us about perseverance through trials?
options: Persevere in faith despite suffering, trusting God's deliverance will come.
Give up when trials become too hard.
Seek revenge on those who persecute you.
Ignore God's word to avoid hardship.
questions.correctAnswer: Persevere in faith despite suffering, trusting God's deliverance will come.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was imprisoned in a dungeon with no water, sinking in mire (38:6), yet he remained faithful and was eventually rescued (38:11-13). This shows perseverance in trials while trusting God's timing for deliverance (38:28).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to conceal God's truth to avoid conflict. Based on Jeremiah 38, what counsel would you give about honesty and integrity in sharing God's message?
options: Speak God's truth openly even if it brings opposition, as Jeremiah did.
Hide God's warnings to maintain popularity.
Change God's message to please others.
Remain silent about difficult truths.
questions.correctAnswer: Speak God's truth openly even if it brings opposition, as Jeremiah did.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah spoke God's warnings to the people despite threats (38:1-4). Though imprisoned, he did not hide God's message (38:25-27). This teaches integrity and courage in proclaiming God's word (38:1-4, 38:25-27).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 38 teach about humility and contentment when facing unjust treatment?
options: Accept suffering with humility, trusting God to uphold justice.
Retaliate against those who wrong you.
Become prideful to protect yourself.
Complain and refuse to serve others.
questions.correctAnswer: Accept suffering with humility, trusting God to uphold justice.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah endured imprisonment and harsh conditions (38:6) without retaliation. His faith in God's justice and deliverance is evident (38:28). This models humility and contentment amid trials (38:6, 38:28).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 38 show the importance of prayerful intercession and seeking God's guidance during crises?
options: The king sought Jeremiah's counsel secretly and promised not to harm him, showing reliance on God's prophet.
The king ignored God's prophet during the crisis.
Rely only on human wisdom and avoid seeking God's guidance.
Avoid difficult conversations about God's will.
questions.correctAnswer: The king sought Jeremiah's counsel secretly and promised not to harm him, showing reliance on God's prophet.
questions.explanation: King Zedekiah took Jeremiah aside to ask questions and promised to keep him safe (38:14-16). This shows the value of prayerful seeking of God's guidance through His prophet in difficult times (38:14-16).

questions.question: A believer faces discouragement because others reject their faithful witness. Based on Jeremiah 38, what biblical principle about evangelism and faithfulness can you share?
options: Remain faithful in proclaiming God's message even if rejected, trusting God to work.
Stop witnessing if people reject the message.
Alter the message to gain approval.
Avoid sharing faith to keep peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Remain faithful in proclaiming God's message even if rejected, trusting God to work.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah faithfully delivered God's warnings despite opposition and imprisonment (38:1-6). He did not alter or hide the message (38:25-27). This exemplifies perseverance in evangelism (38:1-6, 38:25-27).

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 38, the king had full authority to protect Jeremiah but chose not to intervene initially.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: King Zedekiah said Jeremiah was in the princes' hands and that the king could not act against them (38:5). This shows the kingâ€™s limited initial intervention, though he later protected Jeremiah (38:14-16).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 38 teaches that fearing man rather than obeying God leads to destruction and loss.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Zedekiah feared the Jews more than God's command, causing him to hesitate to surrender to Babylon, which Jeremiah warned would bring destruction (38:19-23). Obedience to God was linked to life and preservation (38:17-20).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah was lowered into a dungeon that had no water but ________, causing him to sink while imprisoned.
options: mire
sand
mud
dust
questions.correctAnswer: mire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was cast into a dungeon without water but full of mire, causing him to sink (Jeremiah 38:6). This shows the severity of his suffering.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 38 encourage believers to act with integrity and courage when fellow believers are mistreated?
options: Stand up and intercede for those suffering, like Ebedmelech did for Jeremiah.
Ignore the suffering of others to avoid conflict.
Side with the oppressors to protect yourself.
Avoid involvement in church discipline.
questions.correctAnswer: Stand up and intercede for those suffering, like Ebedmelech did for Jeremiah.
questions.explanation: Ebedmelech courageously approached the king to save Jeremiah and took active steps to rescue him (38:7-13). This models faithfulness and integrity in helping fellow believers (38:7-13).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 38 teach about God's sovereignty and faithfulness when His servants suffer unjustly?
options: God remains sovereign and faithful, preserving His servants despite trials and opposition.
God abandons those who suffer unjustly.
Suffering proves God is displeased with His servants.
God's servants should avoid trials by not speaking truth.
questions.correctAnswer: God remains sovereign and faithful, preserving His servants despite trials and opposition.
questions.explanation: Though Jeremiah was imprisoned unjustly (38:6), God used Ebedmelech and the king to preserve him (38:10-16) and kept Jeremiah alive until Jerusalem's fall (38:28), demonstrating God's sovereignty and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 38 teach us about trusting God's plan even when circumstances look bleak?
options: Trust God's plan for deliverance and life, even when facing imprisonment and destruction.
Give up hope when facing overwhelming odds.
Rely solely on human strength to overcome problems.
Ignore God's warnings to avoid fear.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God's plan for deliverance and life, even when facing imprisonment and destruction.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah trusted God's word despite being thrown into a dungeon (38:6) and encouraged surrender to Babylon for life (38:17-20). God preserved him until Jerusalem's fall (38:28), showing trust in God's plan is essential.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 38 model prayerful dependence in times of uncertainty and danger?
options: Jeremiah sought God's guidance and remained faithful, modeling prayerful dependence despite danger.
Jeremiah acted independently without seeking God.
Jeremiah ignored God's word to protect himself.
Jeremiah avoided difficult situations by running away.
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah sought God's guidance and remained faithful, modeling prayerful dependence despite danger.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah faithfully conveyed God's warnings and counsel to the king (38:14-20), showing dependence on God's word and guidance amid danger (38:1-4, 38:14-20).

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 38.

questions.question: Who were the four men that heard Jeremiah's words and sought to have him put to death?
options: Shephatiah, Gedaliah, Jucal, and Pashur
Ebedmelech, Zedekiah, Mattan, and Hammelech
Jonathan, Pashur, Malchiah, and Shelemiah
Gedaliah, Zedekiah, Malchiah, and Hammelech
questions.correctAnswer: Shephatiah, Gedaliah, Jucal, and Pashur
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:1 lists Shephatiah the son of Mattan, Gedaliah the son of Pashur, Jucal the son of Shelemiah, and Pashur the son of Malchiah as those who heard Jeremiah's words and later sought his death.

questions.question: What was the content of the message Jeremiah delivered that caused the princes to seek his death?
options: The city would fall to the king of Babylon's army
The city would be saved if they fought bravely
The king would defeat the Chaldeans
The famine would end soon
questions.correctAnswer: The city would fall to the king of Babylon's army
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:2-3 records Jeremiah's prophecy that those who remain in the city will die and that the city will be given into the hand of the king of Babylon's army.

questions.question: What reason did the princes give King Zedekiah to justify putting Jeremiah to death?
options: Jeremiah weakens the hands of the men of war and the people by his words
Jeremiah stole from the king's treasury
Jeremiah was collaborating with the Chaldeans
Jeremiah refused to prophesy in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah weakens the hands of the men of war and the people by his words
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:4 explains that the princes accused Jeremiah of weakening the hands of the warriors and people by speaking such words that harm rather than help them.

questions.question: How did King Zedekiah respond to the princes' request to kill Jeremiah?
options: He said Jeremiah was in their hands and he would do nothing
He ordered Jeremiah's immediate execution
He imprisoned Jeremiah in the palace
He sent Jeremiah to Babylon as a hostage
questions.correctAnswer: He said Jeremiah was in their hands and he would do nothing
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:5 shows Zedekiah telling the princes that Jeremiah was in their hands and that the king was powerless to act against them.

questions.question: What type of place was Jeremiah cast into by the princes, and what was its condition?
options: A dungeon with no water but mire, causing Jeremiah to sink
A dark cellar with abundant water and food
A royal prison with guards and provisions
A pit filled with snakes and scorpions
questions.correctAnswer: A dungeon with no water but mire, causing Jeremiah to sink
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:6 describes Jeremiah being cast into the dungeon of Malchiah where there was no water, only mire, and Jeremiah sank in it.

questions.question: Who intervened to save Jeremiah from the dungeon, and what was his position?
options: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, a eunuch in the king's house
Gedaliah the son of Pashur, a prince
Jonathan, a royal guard
The prophet Ezekiel, a fellow prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, a eunuch in the king's house
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:7-8 identifies Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, a eunuch in the king's house, as the one who spoke to the king to rescue Jeremiah.

questions.question: What method did Ebedmelech use to rescue Jeremiah from the dungeon?
options: He lowered old rags and cast clouts by cords to Jeremiah to protect him as they pulled him up
He bribed the guards to free Jeremiah
He dug a tunnel beneath the dungeon walls
He bribed the king to order Jeremiah's release
questions.correctAnswer: He lowered old rags and cast clouts by cords to Jeremiah to protect him as they pulled him up
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:11-13 describe that Ebedmelech took old rags and cast clouts and let them down by cords to Jeremiah to place under his arms to prevent injury while being lifted out.

questions.question: Where did King Zedekiah summon Jeremiah after he was rescued from the dungeon?
options: Into the third entry in the house of the LORD
To the royal throne room
To the prison courtyard
To the king's private chambers
questions.correctAnswer: Into the third entry in the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:14 states that Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah to come into the third entry that is in the house of the LORD to speak with him.

questions.question: What was the condition Zedekiah gave Jeremiah before he revealed what he wanted to ask?
options: To hide nothing and speak openly
To tell only what the king wanted to hear
To speak in riddles
To promise to keep it secret
questions.correctAnswer: To hide nothing and speak openly
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:14 records Zedekiah saying to Jeremiah, 'I will ask thee a thing; hide nothing from me,' indicating his desire for full honesty.

questions.question: What was Jeremiah's concern about telling Zedekiah the LORD's message, and how did the king respond?
options: Jeremiah feared death; Zedekiah swore to protect him
Jeremiah feared exile; Zedekiah promised release
Jeremiah feared imprisonment; Zedekiah ignored him
Jeremiah feared the princes; Zedekiah sided with them
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah feared death; Zedekiah swore to protect him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:15-16 shows Jeremiah's concern that he might be put to death if he spoke, and Zedekiah swore secretly that he would neither kill Jeremiah nor hand him over.

questions.question: What was the prophecy Jeremiah gave to Zedekiah regarding his actions and the fate of the city?
options: If Zedekiah surrenders to the Babylonian princes, he and the city will live; if not, the city will be burned
If Zedekiah fights the Babylonians, he will triumph and the city will be saved
If Zedekiah flees the city, he will be captured but the city will remain
If Zedekiah makes an alliance with Egypt, the city will be spared
questions.correctAnswer: If Zedekiah surrenders to the Babylonian princes, he and the city will live; if not, the city will be burned
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:17-18 states that if Zedekiah goes out to the king of Babylon's princes, his soul will live and the city will not be burned; otherwise, the city will be burned and Zedekiah will not escape.

questions.question: Why was Zedekiah afraid to obey Jeremiah's counsel to surrender to the Babylonians?
options: He feared the Jews who had fallen to the Chaldeans would mock and deliver him
He feared the Babylonians would kill him immediately
He feared the Egyptians would attack
He feared divine punishment for surrendering
questions.correctAnswer: He feared the Jews who had fallen to the Chaldeans would mock and deliver him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:19 shows Zedekiah expressing fear of the Jews who had fallen to the Chaldeans, worrying they might deliver him to them and mock him.

questions.question: What assurance did Jeremiah give to Zedekiah about the loyalty of those Jews who had fallen to the Chaldeans?
options: They would not deliver him if he obeyed the voice of the LORD
They would betray him regardless
They would join the Babylonians against him
They would remain neutral
questions.correctAnswer: They would not deliver him if he obeyed the voice of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:20 assures Zedekiah that those Jews would not deliver him if he obeys the LORD's voice spoken through Jeremiah, promising well-being and life.

questions.question: What was the prophetic imagery used to describe what would happen if Zedekiah refused to surrender, involving the king's wives and children?
options: They would be brought out to the king of Babylon's princes, signaling defeat and humiliation
They would be hidden safely within the city
They would lead a revolt against the Babylonians
They would be sent as ambassadors to Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: They would be brought out to the king of Babylon's princes, signaling defeat and humiliation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:22-23 prophesies that the remaining women, wives, and children of the king would be brought out to the Babylonians, indicating total defeat and humiliation.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah was kept in the court of the prison until the day Jerusalem was captured.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:28 states that Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison until Jerusalem was taken, and he was present at its capture.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 38 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who were the four men that heard Jeremiah's prophecy to the people in Jeremiah 38?
options: Shephatiah, Gedaliah, Jucal, and Pashur
Ebedmelech, Zedekiah, Mattan, Hammelech
Nebuchadnezzar, Gedaliah, Shelemiah, Malchiah
Jonathan, Malchiah, Shelemiah, Ebedmelech
questions.correctAnswer: Shephatiah, Gedaliah, Jucal, and Pashur
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:1 explicitly names Shephatiah the son of Mattan, Gedaliah the son of Pashur, Jucal the son of Shelemiah, and Pashur the son of Malchiah as hearing Jeremiah's words. This shows the opposition to his prophecy within the leadership. Similar leadership opposition to prophets is seen in 1 Kings 18:17-18 and Acts 7:51.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 38, what will happen to those who remain in the city?
options: They shall die by the sword, famine, and pestilence
They shall be saved by God's intervention
They shall be carried into exile peacefully
They shall conquer the Chaldeans
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die by the sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:2 states that those who remain in the city will die by sword, famine, and pestilence, highlighting the divine judgment on the unrepentant. This aligns with God's justice as seen in Deuteronomy 28:21-22 and the judgment on Jerusalem in Ezekiel 14:21.

questions.question: Why did the princes want Jeremiah put to death, according to Jeremiah 38?
options: Because he weakened the hands of the men of war and the people
Because he conspired with the king of Babylon
Because he stole from the temple treasury
Because he refused to eat in the palace
questions.correctAnswer: Because he weakened the hands of the men of war and the people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:4 reveals that the princes accused Jeremiah of weakening the morale of the soldiers and people by speaking words that did not seek their welfare but harm. This reflects the conflict between divine truth and human expectations, similar to Nathan's confrontation with David (2 Samuel 12) and the rejection of prophets in Jeremiah 26:8-11.

questions.question: What was King Zedekiah's response when the princes asked him to put Jeremiah to death?
options: He said Jeremiah was in their hand and the king could do nothing
He immediately ordered Jeremiah's execution
He protected Jeremiah and hid him
He sent Jeremiah to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: He said Jeremiah was in their hand and the king could do nothing
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:5 shows Zedekiah deferring to the princes, indicating his weakness or political caution. This shows the human frailty of leaders under pressure, a theme echoed in Judges 8:22-23 and John 19:10-11 where earthly rulers are limited by God's sovereignty.

questions.question: What conditions did Jeremiah face in the dungeon where he was cast?
options: No water, only mire, causing him to sink
Comfortable bedding and food
A dry, well-ventilated cell
A guarded palace chamber
questions.correctAnswer: No water, only mire, causing him to sink
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:6 describes the dungeon as lacking water but full of mire, so Jeremiah sank into it, symbolizing his suffering and isolation. This suffering of God's messenger reflects the affliction of the righteous in Psalm 40:2 and the trials of the apostles in 2 Corinthians 11:23-27.

questions.question: Who intervened to rescue Jeremiah from the dungeon?
options: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, a eunuch in the king's house
Zedekiah the king himself
The princes who imprisoned him
Jonathan, a Levite priest
questions.correctAnswer: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, a eunuch in the king's house
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:7-8 identifies Ebedmelech, an Ethiopian eunuch, as the one who heard of Jeremiah's plight and spoke to the king to save him. This shows God's use of unexpected instruments for deliverance, paralleling the help of the widow in 1 Kings 17:10-16 and Philip's ministry to the Ethiopian eunuch in Acts 8:26-40.

questions.question: What method was used to rescue Jeremiah from the dungeon?
options: Lowering old cloths and rags under the cords to protect him while lifting him
Digging a tunnel to free him
Breaking down the dungeon walls
Bribing the guards to release him
questions.correctAnswer: Lowering old cloths and rags under the cords to protect him while lifting him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:11-12 describes Ebedmelech lowering old cast clouts and rotten rags under Jeremiah's armholes to protect him from the cords during the rescue. This reflects practical wisdom and care, reminiscent of the protective care God provides as in Psalm 91 and the use of ropes in Acts 9:25 to protect Paul.

questions.question: What promise did King Zedekiah make to Jeremiah before seeking his counsel?
options: He would not put Jeremiah to death nor deliver him to those seeking his life
He would crown Jeremiah as a prince
He would exile Jeremiah to Egypt
He would imprison Jeremiah again if he disobeyed
questions.correctAnswer: He would not put Jeremiah to death nor deliver him to those seeking his life
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:16 records Zedekiah swearing secretly that he would neither kill Jeremiah nor hand him over to his enemies, demonstrating a moment of trust. This mirrors God's covenantal promises of preservation in Isaiah 43:2 and the protection promised to the faithful in Romans 8:31-39.

questions.question: What conditional prophecy did Jeremiah give to King Zedekiah about the city's fate?
options: If Zedekiah surrenders to the king of Babylon, his life will be spared and the city saved from fire
If Zedekiah fights the Chaldeans, he will conquer them
If Zedekiah flees the city, he will become king of Babylon
If Zedekiah ignores the prophecy, the city will prosper
questions.correctAnswer: If Zedekiah surrenders to the king of Babylon, his life will be spared and the city saved from fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:17 explains that surrendering to Babylon's princes would preserve Zedekiah's life and prevent the city's destruction by fire. This reflects the biblical principle of repentance and obedience bringing life, as in 2 Chronicles 36:15-16 and Jesus' call to repent in Luke 13:3.

questions.question: What fear did Zedekiah express to Jeremiah regarding surrendering to the Babylonians?
options: He feared the Jews who fell to the Chaldeans would betray and mock him
He feared the Babylonians would kill him immediately
He feared losing his throne to Nebuchadnezzar
He feared Jeremiah's counsel was false
questions.correctAnswer: He feared the Jews who fell to the Chaldeans would betray and mock him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:19 shows Zedekiah's fear of betrayal and mockery from his own people who had been captured by the Chaldeans, illustrating the human anxiety in trusting God's word despite opposition. This is consistent with the fear of man versus fear of God taught in Proverbs 29:25 and Jesus' exhortation in Matthew 10:28.

questions.question: How did Jeremiah reassure Zedekiah regarding his fear of the Jews delivering him to the Babylonians?
options: Jeremiah said they would not deliver him and urged obedience to God's voice
Jeremiah told him to flee the city immediately
Jeremiah advised him to form alliances with Edomites
Jeremiah promised the Babylonians would be defeated
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah said they would not deliver him and urged obedience to God's voice
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:20 conveys Jeremiah's assurance that the Jews would not betray Zedekiah if he obeyed God's voice, emphasizing divine protection for those who trust God. This assurance reflects God's faithfulness in Psalm 34:15-19 and Christ's promise of protection in John 10:27-28.

questions.question: What did Jeremiah say would happen if Zedekiah refused to go to the king of Babylon's princes?
options: The city would be burned, his wives and children taken, and he captured
He would reign longer as king
He would escape to Egypt safely
The Babylonians would be defeated by the Egyptians
questions.correctAnswer: The city would be burned, his wives and children taken, and he captured
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:22-23 prophesies that refusal to surrender would lead to the city's burning and the capture of Zedekiah's family and himself, exemplifying the certainty of divine judgment upon disobedience. This fits with God's warnings in Deuteronomy 28 and the fulfillment recorded in 2 Kings 25.

questions.question: What instructions did Zedekiah give Jeremiah regarding the secrecy of their conversation?
options: That no one should know of the words and Jeremiah would not die
That Jeremiah should publicly announce the prophecy
That Jeremiah should write the words in the temple
That Jeremiah should flee the city immediately
questions.correctAnswer: That no one should know of the words and Jeremiah would not die
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:24 records Zedekiah's command to keep their conversation secret to protect Jeremiah's life. This shows the political tension and danger surrounding prophetic truth, akin to the secrecy requested in Judges 13:5 and Paul's guarded ministry in Acts 20:29-30.

questions.question: When the princes questioned Jeremiah about his conversation with the king, how did Jeremiah respond?
options: He told them he prayed not to be returned to Jonathan's house to die
He revealed the king's full counsel
He denied speaking with the king
He fled the court to avoid them
questions.correctAnswer: He told them he prayed not to be returned to Jonathan's house to die
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:26-27 shows Jeremiah giving a limited answer to the princes, saying he petitioned the king not to send him back to die in Jonathan's house, avoiding revealing the king's full counsel. This displays prudence in a hostile environment, reflecting Jesus' measured answers before hostile authorities (Matthew 26:62-64).

questions.question: How long did Jeremiah remain in the court of the prison, and what significant event did he witness there?
options: Until Jerusalem was taken; he was there during the city's fall
Until the Babylonians withdrew; he was released then
Until the king died; then he was exiled
Until the Chaldeans crowned him king
questions.correctAnswer: Until Jerusalem was taken; he was there during the city's fall
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 38:28 states that Jeremiah stayed in the prison court until Jerusalem's capture, witnessing the fulfillment of his prophecies. This endurance under persecution illustrates God's sovereign plan unfolding, echoing Daniel's faithfulness in exile (Daniel 6) and Christ's foreknowledge of Jerusalem's fall (Luke 19:41-44).
